titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller Foundation records, Field Offices, New Delhi, India, RG 6, SG 7

did.unittitle: Rockefeller Foundation records, field offices, New Delhi, India, RG 6, SG 7

prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: RG 6.7 is arranged in three subgroups, corresponding to program or program area, and thereunder in series.
Subgroup I, Indian Agricultural Program, is comprised of seven series:

Series 1 - General Administrative Files Series 2 - IAP Administrative Files Series 3 - Officers' Diaries Series 4 - Crop Improvement Programs Series 5 - Agricultural Education Series 6 - Agricultural Research Institutes Series 7 - Personnel Files
In accordance with RF policy, Series VII is closed to research. Series III, Officers' Diaries, is open with the permission of the Director of the Archive Center.
Subgroup II, Medical and Natural Sciences Program, has been arranged in three series:
Series 1 - Administrative Files Series 2 - All India Institute of Medical Sciences Series 3 - Virus Research Center, Poona
Subgroup III, Humanities and Social Sciences Program, includes
Series 1 - General Correspondence Series 2 - Socio-Economic Study in Uttar Pradesh

Within series, records are typically arranged alphabetically by subject or type of material and thereunder chronologically. The original folder titles given by field office personnel at the time or records transfer to New York in 1973 have been retained. Series were established by the processing archivist in 1994.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: From 1935 to 1973, the New Delhi Field Office of the Rockefeller Foundation (RF) administered cooperative programs throughout India in the fields of medicine and public health (1935-1973), agriculture (1956-73), and the humanities and social sciences (1964-72). The New Delhi office also served as the RF's Far Eastern regional headquarters, replacing Shanghai temporarily from 1942 to 1946 and permanently after 1949. Between 1949 and 1952, the office was located in Bangalore.

The New Delhi office was headed by the Field Director or Foundation Representative in India, who served as a scientist-cum-administrator and reported to the appropriate division director in New York. His staff included an Assistant Field Director, staff scientists and research assistants, and local administrative personnel. The field office staff was continually augmented by visiting specialists from around the world. By 1966, the fifteen-member staff in New Delhi constituted the largest RF contingent outside New York.

The RF's International Health Division (IHD) had established the first office in New Delhi for the purpose of extending its India hookworm control program, which had begun in the Madras Presidency in 1920. Subsequent medical and public health activities in India included malaria control, the development of demonstration health units, nursing education, nutrition studies, and, increasingly throughout the 1950s and 1960s, medical education and research. Significant grants went to the All India Institute of Hygiene and Public Health in Calcutta (1913-50) and the Virus Research Center at Poona (1951-71). Grants also supported the Indian Council for Medical Research and the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (1952-1973).

The last year in which grants were made in the medical field from the New Delhi office was 1970. At that time, the RF's Medical and Natural Sciences division separated into two distinct disciplines, Biomedical Sciences and Natural and Environmental Sciences.

The RF's agricultural work in India officialy began in 1956 when the Government of India and the RF signed a Memorandum of Understanding. This agreement created the Indian Agricultural Program (IAP) and spread the so-called Green Revolution to India. The IAP was the fourth in a series of ambitious "country" programs in agriculture begun by the RF in Mexico (1943) and subsequently extended to Colombia (1950) and Chile (1955). Its purpose was twofold: to increase cereal crop production through the development of high-yielding seed, and to strengthen graduate education in agriculture. Under the Memorandum of Understanding, the Government of India arranged for the necessary land and facilities and budget for local staff, while the RF provided a permanent staff of resident specialists and appropriated annual sums for equipment and other expenses incurred by the field programs. The Foundation also made grants to selected agricultural institutions and to Indian scientists to pursue research in the United States.

Research and postgraduate training were viewed as interrelated activities. In 1958, with the Foundation's support, a postgraduate school was inaugurated at the Indian Agricultural Research Institute, New Delhi (est. 1905), with the authority to award the M.Sc. and Ph.D. degrees. After 1960, new legislation made possible the creation of several state agricultural universities modeled after American land-grant universities. These universities developed relationships with the various crop improvement programs and offered valuable research opportunities for American and Indian agronomists.

The All India Coordinated Cereal Improvement Projects, the backbone of the IAP research program, represented a new approach to crop research in India. Sponsored by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) and jointly operated by the ICAR and state institutions, each project studies the agronomy, entomology, pathology, genetics, and breeding of an individual crop. For the first time, research stations and substations were established throughout the subcontinent in order to coordinate research activities across the major agro-climatic zones. The programs began with maize in 1957 (although maize work had begun in India in 1945) and came to include sorghum and other millets (1957), wheat (1961), and rice (1965). Notable increases occurred in wheat production with the importation in 1965 of dwarf materials from Mexico. In conducting seed development research, the IAP benefited from the expertise of those RF agronomists who had served first in Mexico, namely Edwin J. Wellhausen, Ulysses J. Grant, Ernest W. Sprague, and the 1970 Nobel Prize winner, Norman E. Borlaug. Allied areas of research included drainage, fertility, soil and water management, and agricultural economics.

In 1973, the RF decided to bring to a close its Indian Agricultural Program. India continued to carry out crop improvement work, utilizing the administrative, teaching, and research structures jointly established over seventeen years by the IAP and the Government of India. The RF therefore phased out its involvement in all improvement programs except rice, which was continued until 1975 by Wayne H. Freeman at Hyderabad. From 1976 to 1983, the Hyderabad office under Leland R. House operated the International Crops Research Institute for the Semi-Arid Tropics (ICRISAT). This institute functioned as part of the Foundation's "Conquest of Hunger" program, which had been formally established in 1963.

In October 1964, Chadbourne Gilpatric took up residence in India as Visiting Professor in Philosophy at Delhi University, with responsibilities for representing RF interests in the Humanities and Social Sciences (HSS). Under HSS director Joseph E. Black (1964-70), Gilpatric sought to advance research and teaching in the humanities and in the social and hard sciences. He was particularly eager to strengthen curriculum at agricultural universities and to increase and preserve library holdings. From 1968 to 1972, Gilpatric coordinated a socioeconomic study of small farmers in Uttar Pradesh state. Gilpatric returned to the United States in April 1972. The Social Sciences programs had been officially phased out in 1970 and replaced with separate Arts and Humanities divisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The New Delhi Field Office records (RG 6.7) of the Rockefeller Foundation Archives document the operation of the office and the programs it administered in the medical, agricultural, and social sciences. The records span the dates 1935 to 1976, but 90% of the record group dates from the period 1956 to 1973 and relates to the Indian Agricultural Program (IAP), operated by the RF's Natural Sciences and Agriculture Division. The IAP records provide a comprehensive account of the RF's role in establishing an international collaborative program of technical assistance. They also constitute an important source for the study of the history of modern agriculture and agricultural education in India.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important Subjects:

Agricultural education--India; Agricultural experiment stations--India; Agricultural innovation--India; Agriculture and state--India; Agriculture--Asia; Agriculture--India --Green Revolution --High Yielding Varieties Programs; Indian Council of Agricultural Research (New Delhi); Indian Agricultural Research Institute (New Delhi); International Rice Research Institute (Philippines); Plant introduction--India; Virology--Research--India; New Delhi--Charitable uses, trusts, and foundations; Rockefeller Foundation--India; --Rockefeller Foundation--Division of Natural Sciences and Agriculture--India; United States Agency for International Development.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important Names:

Allen, LeRoy R.; Anderson, Richmond K.; Baird, Guy B.; Balfour, Marshall C.; Barnard, Chester Irving; Borlaug, Norman Ernest; Bugher, John C.; Corwin, J.D.; Cummings, Ralph Waldo; Douglas, Johnson E.; Fosdick, Raymond Blaine; Freeman, Wayne H.; Gilpatric, Chadbourne; Grant, Ulysses J.; Gregg, Lucien A.; Harrar, Jacob George; House, Leland Ralph; Joshi, A. B.; Kerr, J. Austin; Mason, Max; Morison, Robert S.; Moseman, Albert H.; Pal, Benjamin Peary; Parker, Dorothy; Rachie, Kenneth O.; Rusk, Dean; Sprague, Ernest W.; Stakman, Elvin Charles; Starnes, Ordway; Strode, George K.; Swaminathan, S.; Warren, Andrew J.; Weaver, Warren; Weir, John; Wellhausen, Edwin J.; Work, Telford H.; Wortman, Sterling.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Max Mason, 1929-36; Raymond B. Fosdick, 1936-48; Chester I. Barnard, 1948-51; Dean Rusk, 1951-61; J. George Harrar, 1961-72; John H. Knowles, 1972-79.

Foundation Representatives in New Delhi: W.P. Jacocks, 1935-42; Marshall C. Balfour, 1942-46, 1949, 1954-58; Miss J. D. Corwin, 1946-48; Richmond K. Anderson, 1948-54; LeRoy R. Allen, 1958-67; Division Directors in New York: Richard M. Pearce (Medical Sciences), 1929-30; Alan Gregg (Medical Sciences), 1931-50; George K. Strode (Medicine and Public Health), 1951; Andrew J. Warren (Medicine and Public Health), 1951-54; John C. Bugher (Medical Education and Public Health), 1955-59; Robert S. Morison (Biological and Medical Research), 1955-59; (Medical and Natural Sciences), 1964-70; John M. Weir (Medical and Natural Sciences), 1964-70.
Field Directors in New Delhi: Ralph W. Cummings, 1957-66; Guy B. Baird, 1967-71; Ordway Starnes, 1971-73; Wayne H. Freeman, 1974-75

Division Directors in New York: Warren Weaver (Natural Sciences and Agriculture), 1951-55; J. George Harrar (Agricultural Sciences), 1955-59; Albert H. Moseman (Agricultural Sciences), 1960-65; Sterling Wortman (Agricultural Sciences), 1966-70; John A. Pino (Agricultural Sciences), 1970-82.
Foundation Representative in New Delhi: Chadbourne Gilpatric (Humanities and Social Sciences), 1964-72.

Division Directors in New York: Kenneth W. Thompson, acting (Humanities and Social Sciences), 1962-64; Joseph E. Black (Humanities and Social Sciences), 1964-70; Norman Lloyd (Arts and Humanities), 1970-73.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: For information about specific grants to individuals or institutions in India, researchers should consult the grant files (1913-73) for India, located in Record Groups 1.1 and 1.2 (Projects), Series 464 (India), in the Rockefeller Foundation Archives.
The following Record Groups in the Rockefeller Foundation Archives at the Rockefeller Archive Center contain material bearing upon the Foundation's work in India:

RG 1.1: Projects; RG 1.2: Projects; RG 2: General Correspondence; RG 3: Administration, Program, and Policy; RG 5: International Health Board; RG 6.13: Mexico Field Office; RG 12: Officers' Diaries; RG 13: Oral Histories, RF Field Officers.
Annual reports of the Rockefeller Foundation; Confidential Monthly Report, for the Information of the Trustees.

Four folders of photographs were removed from Record Group 6.7 during processing and added to the Photograph Collection of the Archive Center. These photographs are filed by country number, 464 India, and thereunder alphabetically by subject. They are interfiled with other photographs of India taken from Record Group 1.1 and 1.2 (Projects). Included are photographs of CIMMYT work in Mexico (n.d.), agricultural scenes in India (1958-59), compartment cages used for rearing the sorghum shoot fly (1971), and a disbound scrapbook of captioned photographs (1957) showing investigations into the virus known as Kyasanoor Forest Disease.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Records more than 20 years old are open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

did.unittitle: Indian Agricultural Program - General Administrative Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subgroup I, Series 1, General Administrative Files (1952-1976), contains correspondence and miscellaneous materials pertaining to general field office operations. Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by subject. Filed under "Government of India" are copies of agreements and understandings (1957-1976) reached between the RF and the Indian government. The bulk of the Government of India correspondence consists of letters between the field office, government ministries, and New York headquarters concerning Indian government procedures for proposing and clearing grants to agencies or institutions in India. It also covers procedures for reporting renewals, extensions, or amendments of fellowships; sending dollar checks to the United States; and preparing income tax reports. Additional correspondence concerns budgetary matters, field office bank accounts, employee housing, and staffing of the American International School, where RF staff enrolled their children.

Other material in Series 1 is filed under the heading "Operating Records" and fills boxes 7-21. Operating records include customs clearance permits, leases for rented offices and apartments in New Delhi, personnel policy files, record-keeping procedures, and inventories of imported field equipment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subgroup I, Series 2, IAP Administrative Files, includes correspondence, minutes, program development files, and fellowship and scholarship files (1950-1975) relating to the planning and review of the IAP research programs and to international programs with which the Foundation collaborated.

Field office correspondence with New York headquarters, the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR), and the Ministry of Food and Agricultural fills boxes 22 through 25. Correspondence with the New York office relates to travel, staffing needs, funding, equipment and supplies, and seed shipments. Letters between IAP field directors and the Directors General of the ICAR, Dr. B. P. Pal and Dr. A. B. Joshi, pertain to meetings and workshops, crop programs, research evaluations and publications.

Correspondence with representatives of international organizations and agencies is arranged alphabetically by country or name of organization and fills boxes 29 through 33. Letters concern agriculture assistance programs undertaken by other organizations, as well as preparations for IAP staff visits to countries outside India. As a whole, the correspondence reveals the international network of technical know-how brought to bear upon improving Asian agriculture between 1958 and 1973.

The program development files in Series 2 contain influential reports on RF agricultural policy and Indian agriculture. These include a statement by RF Director Warren Weaver, "The Program in the Natural Sciences," prepared in 1950, one year before the creation of the Natural Sciences and Agriculture Division. Also present is a 1951 memorandum from Weaver to Dr. Richmond K. Anderson, the RF Representative in India, in which Weaver outlines procedures for referring to New York Indian requests for information on agricultural grants. Also of interest is the 1952 report, "Notes on Indian Agriculture," by J. G. Harrar, Paul C. Mangelsdorf, and Warren Weaver. This report led to several follow-up visits by RF representatives and ultimately to India's request for a collaborative agricultural program.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Records are arranged alphabetically by type of material from "Correspondence" through "Program development files." These files are followed by International Development Programs, International Organizations, and United States Agencies.
Correspondence with representatives of international organizations and agencies is arranged alphabetically by country or name of organization.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: Additional material on international collaboration is contained in Series 4, Crop Improvement Programs, and Series 6, Agricultural Research Institutes. Series 4 includes information on the Inter-Asian Corn Improvement Program (1963-1973), other international maize assistance programs (1961-1971), and the IRRI (International Rice Research Institute) (1967-1973). Correspondence relating to CIMMYT (Centro International de Mejoramiento de Maiz y Trigo) and its cooperation with the All India Maize and Wheat programs is contained in Series 6, Subseries 3.
Additional reports on Indian agriculture are located in Record Group 1.1 (Projects), Series 464 (India).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 3 contains the daily office diaries of IAP Field Directors Ralph W. Cummings (1957-1966), Guy B. Baird (1959-1971), Ordway Starnes (1971-1973), and RF Representative Wayne H. Freeman (1974-1975). These diaries provide a nearly unbroken account of the writers' administrative and scientific activities, constituting a unique source of information and commentary. Diary entries were generally hand-written and then typed by an assistant. The field office retained a copy, and the original type-written copy was sent to New York with one or two carbon copies for filing in other office correspondence. Thus, excerpts of these diaries appear in Record Group 1.1 (Projects) and 1.2 (Projects) and occasionally in Record Group 2 (General Correspondence).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Alphabetically arranged by author.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Officers' diaries are open for scholarly research provided that (1) the diarist is deceased and (2) the volume to be examined is at least twenty years old. All reasonable efforts will be made to determine the fate of the diarist(s), but if such efforts are fruitless then the material will remain closed to scholarly research until 100 years after the officer's year of birth.

did.unittitle: Indian Agricultural Program - Crop Improvement Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 4, Crop Improvement Programs, is the largest of the series in Subgroup I (boxes 39 to 94) and contains the records of the All India Coordinated Crop Improvement programs, the seed development program, and miscellaneous food study programs.

Certain types of records are common to Subseries 1 through 6. Correspondence relating to the establishment and organization of the particular program appears first within each subseries. Substantial correspondence exists for maize (1957-72), millet (1965-68, 1970-71), rice (1964-83), sorghum (1957-73), wheat (1965-73), and seed development (1959-73). Correspondence of a miscellaneous character follows, treating such technical matters as experiment station operations, equipment maintenance, conference and workshop scheduling, training programs, relations with other agricultural organizations, and research programs in seed collection, breeding, entomology and pathology.

Correspondence is typically followed by unpublished and published reports summarizing the results of experimental tests. These reports are arranged alphabetically by corporate author in Subseries 1, Maize, and alphabetically by title throughout the rest of the series. Filed with unpublished reports are manuscript drafts of reports on various aspects of the research programs. Also present are "trip reports" written by staff from the field.

Published materials include the annual Progress Reports of the various All India Coordinated Crop Improvement Programs, conference proceedings, special reports, Foundation reports, monographs, periodicals, and offprints.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in ten subseries:

Subseries 1 - Maize Subseries 2 - Millet Subseries 3 - Rice Subseries 4 - Seed Development Subseries 5 - Sorghum Subseries 6 - Wheat Subseries 7 - Miscellaneous IAP Staff Projects Subseries 8 - Miscellaneous Food, Crop, and Study Programs Subseries 9 - USAID Projects Under Public Law 480 Subseries 10 - Miscellaneous Reports
Within subseries, records are arranged alphabetically by subject or type of material and thereunder chronologically.

did.unittitle: Indian Agricultural Program - Crop Improvement Programs - Maize

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence relating to the establishment and organization of the maize program appears first within this subseries. Correspondence of a miscellaneous character follows, treating such technical matters as experiment station operations, equipment maintenance, conference and workshop scheduling, training programs, relations with other agricultural organizations, and research programs in seed collection, breeding, entomology and pathology.

Correspondence is typically followed by unpublished and published reports summarizing the results of experimental tests. These reports are arranged alphabetically by corporate author. Filed with unpublished reports are manuscript drafts of reports on various aspects of the research programs. Also present are "trip reports" written by staff from the field.

Indian Agricultural Program - Crop Improvement Programs - Millet (All India Coordinated Millet Improvement Program)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence relating to the establishment and organization of the millet program appears first within this subseries. Correspondence of a miscellaneous character follows, treating such technical matters as experiment station operations, equipment maintenance, conference and workshop scheduling, training programs, relations with other agricultural organizations, and research programs in seed collection, breeding, entomology and pathology.

Correspondence is typically followed by unpublished and published reports summarizing the results of experimental tests. These reports are arranged alphabetically by title. Filed with unpublished reports are manuscript drafts of reports on various aspects of the research programs. Also present are "trip reports" written by staff from the field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence relating to the establishment and organization of the rice program appears first within Subseries 3. Correspondence of a miscellaneous character follows, treating such technical matters as experiment station operations, equipment maintenance, conference and workshop scheduling, training programs, relations with other agricultural organizations, and research programs in seed collection, breeding, entomology and pathology.

Correspondence is typically followed by unpublished and published reports summarizing the results of experimental tests. These reports are arranged alphabetically by title. Filed with unpublished reports are manuscript drafts of reports on various aspects of the research programs. Also present are "trip reports" written by staff from the field. Subseries 3 contains the trip reports of Wayne H. Freeman (1968-1973).

Correspondence of a miscellaneous character follows, treating such technical matters as experiment station operations, equipment maintenance, conference and workshop scheduling, training programs, relations with other agricultural organizations, and research programs in seed collection, breeding, entomology and pathology.

Correspondence is typically followed by unpublished and published reports summarizing the results of experimental tests. These reports are arranged alphabetically by title. Filed with unpublished reports are manuscript drafts of reports on various aspects of the research programs. Also present are "trip reports" written by staff from the field. Wheat geneticist R. Glenn Anderson's trip reports on wheat research can be found in Subseries 6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 5, Agricultural Education documents the RF's role in strengthening graduate agricultural education in India. The establishment of state agricultural universities, where Indian scientists could receive training, was deemed central to the success of the Indian Agricultural Program. A twin goal was the creation of a postgraduate school at the Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI), which occurred in 1958.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series 5, Agricultural Education, has been arranged in two subseries:
Subseries 1 - General Files
Subseries 2 - Institutional Files

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Subgroup I, Series 6 - Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes.

did.unittitle: Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Education - General Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The role of the IAP's first Field Director, Ralph W. Cummings, in developing academic standards is documented in Subseries 1 by files of the Agricultural Universities Committee (1961-1966). The committee, with Cummings serving as chairman, drew up the guidelines for the establishment of agricultural universities which were later codified in the Model Act for Agricultural Universities (1966). The Model Act with attached correspondence is located in Box 96.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Subseries 1 includes general correspondence arranged alphabetically by subject.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Subgroup I, Series 6 - Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Actual dates of this subseries are: 1955-56, 1959-66, 1968, 1970-73.

Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Education - Institutional Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries 2, Institutional Files, contains six boxes of correspondence concerning the establishment and operation of fourteen agricultural universities and their relationship to the various All India Crop Improvement programs. Especially well documented are the Andhra Pradesh Agricultural University (1959-1973), Madhya Pradesh Agricultural University (1961-1973), Mysore University of Agricultural Sciences (1961-1973), Punjab Agricultural University (1959-1973), Rajasthan Agricultural University (1960-1973), and Uttar Pradesh Agricultural University (1957-1973).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The files in Subseries 2 are arranged alphabetically by educational institution.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Subgroup I, Series 6 - Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes.

Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 6, Agricultural Research Institutes, documents the RF's role in strengthening graduate agricultural education in India. The establishment of state agricultural universities, where Indian scientists could receive training, was deemed central to the success of the Indian Agricultural Program. A twin goal was the creation of a postgraduate school at the Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI), which occurred in 1958.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Series 6, Agricultural Research Institutes, is arranged into three subseries:
Subseries 1 - Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI)
Subseries 2 - Indian Institutions and Organizations
Subseries 3 - International Research Institutes
Within subseries, records are arranged alphabetically by subject, type of material, or name of institution.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also Subgroup I, Series 5 - Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Education.

did.unittitle: Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes - Indian Agricultural Research Institute (IARI)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries 1 (boxes 102-110) relates exclusively to the establishment and operation of the IARI Post Graduate School; it is divided into general correspondence and postgraduate school correspondence. General correspondence includes the office correspondence (1957-1973) of the IARI Director B. P. Pal; however, the bulk of the correspondence pertains to the IARI Department of Farm Operation and Management. This department provided farming service to the field work of all IARI divisions. These services included land preparation, irrigation, and machinery operation and maintenance. Among the correspondents are IARI directors B. P. Pal, A. B. Joshi, M. S. Swaminathan, and K. Kanungo, and Foundation Field Directors Ralph Cummings, Guy B. Baird, and Ordway Starnes.

Postgraduate school correspondence (1956-1973) relates to the administration and organization of the school, in which IAP Field Director, Ralph W. Cummings played a leading role. He began discussions with IARI faculty and staff in January 1957 and served as the school's Acting Dean from 1959-1960. He was succeeded in 1960 by A. B. Joshi.

Interfiled within the correspondence are minutes of faculty meetings and academic council meetings. Additional correspondence pertains to student eligibility for RF assistantships at IARI (1961-1973) and to academic divisions (1956-1973), especially Agricultural Engineering, Agricultural Physics, Farm Operations and Management, Genetics, and the Water Technology Centre.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Records are arranged alphabetically by subject, type of material, or name of institution.

Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes - Indian Institutions and Organizations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In addition to the IARI in New Delhi, the RF assisted many Indian colleges, laboratories, and research institutes engaged in agronomic research and training. Subseries 2, Indian Institutions and Organizations, contains correspondence relating to RF support for such institutes, which generally included providing consultants, supplying and maintaining equipment, or recommending candidates to fill teaching positions. Files include RF evaluations of these institutes and their programs.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Records are arranged alphabetically by subject, type of material, or name of institution.

Indian Agricultural Program - Agricultural Research Institutes - International Research Institutes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subseries 3, International Research Institutes, contains correspondence between the Delhi office and non-Indian research centers, including the Centro Internacional de Agricultura Tropical (CIAT) (1955-1973), Centro Internacional de Mejoramiento de Maiz y Trigo (CIMMYT) (1969-1973), and the International Uplands Crop Research Institute (1970-1973).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Records are arranged alphabetically by subject, type of material, or name of institution.

Medical and Natural Sciences Program - Administrative Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records in Subgroup II, Medical and Natural Sciences Program, offer evidence of the RF's increasing support for medical education and public health, recognized by the creation in 1951 of the Division of Medicine and Public Health (MEPH).

Series 1, Administrative Files, dates from 1935, the year in which the RF began operations in New Delhi. Annual reports (1935-1973) from the RF's Representative in New Delhi to the Government of India provide valuable summaries of work in progress and identify current office staff. In their correspondence (1957-1958), John C. Bugher, director (1955-1959) of MEPH, and John M. Weir, Associate Director (1955-1959), discuss the desirability of combining the medical and agricultural programs in one New Delhi office. Other correspondents include LeRoy R. Allen, Representative in India and Consultant to the AIIMS (1960-1967), and Lucien A. Gregg, Adviser to the Director of the AIIMS (1958-1962).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records in Subgroup II, Medical and Natural Sciences Program, offer evidence of the RF's increasing support for medical education and public health, recognized by the creation in 1951 of the Division of Medicine and Public Health (MEPH).

Files in Series 2, All India Institute of Medical Sciences, relate to three cooperative programs of the AIIMS: the Comprehensive Rural Health Services Project at Ballabhgarh (1960-1973), the joint Harvard-AIIMS project to study health and population pressures in rural communities (1966-1967), and a staff exchange program with the Massachusetts General Hospital (1962, 1964-1967), which was never implemented. The Ballabhgarh project is the most fully documented. This was a cooperative program of the AIIMS, the Government of Hariana, and the RF, which sought to build and operate rural health centers and conduct family planning studies. LeRoy R. Allen served as Project Director. Files include data on family planning (1965-1967), site plans for hospital construction (1964-1965), budget summaries (1964-1968), and correspondence with temporary field staff.

Medical and Natural Sciences Program - Virus Research Center, Poona

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records in Subgroup II, Medical and Natural Sciences Program, offer evidence of the RF's increasing support for medical education and public health, recognized by the creation in 1951 of the Division of Medicine and Public Health (MEPH).

Early in 1951, a Virus Research Center was established in Poona in cooperation with the Indian Council of Medical Research. Files retained by the New Delhi office document the center's establishment, administration, and research program. They are located in Series 3.

In October 1951, Dr. J. Austin Kerr arrived to organize and direct the Virus Research Center. Kerr's correspondence and that of his successor, Telford H. Work, is filed under "Director's office correspondence." This correspondence fills nine folders and is arranged in groupings designated by the field office: New York office, New Delhi office, Indian Council of Medical Research, and colleagues in India. Files include both incoming and outgoing correspondence with these other offices and individuals.

Research centered on the identification and isolation of Indian viruses transmitted by blood-sucking arthropods. Files relating to individual viruses are arranged by virus name. Interim activity reports (1952-1957) provide information on ongoing virus work. The Calcutta School of Tropical Medicine and the Indian Veterinary Research Institute at Izatnagar participated in the research effort; correspondence between Poona and these institutions is filed at the end of Series 3.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The files in this series are arranged alphabetically by subject.

Humanities and Social Sciences Program - General Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The activities of the Humanities and Social Sciences (HSS) division in India stemmed from the successful work of the Indian Agricultural Program. Chadbourne Gilpatric, RF Representative for HSS, saw the opportunity to strengthen agricultural education by developing a stronger humanities and social sciences curriculum for the agricultural universities. He also sought support for Indian universities generally. Gilpatric's vision of the role of the HSS division in India is documented in his correspondence (1964-1973) with the New York office, contained in Series 1.

did.unittitle: Humanities and Social Sciences Program - Socio-Economic Study in Uttar Pradesh

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Series 2 includes the project papers for the Socio-Economic Study in Uttar Pradesh, which ran from 1967 to 1972 under the direction of Chadbourne Gilpatric, RF Representative for Humanities and Social Sciences (HSS). This was a pilot study of the economic behavior of progressive farmers in four blocks of northwestern Uttar Pradesh. Research files contain correspondence (1967-1972) with New York headquarters and members of the research team, field investigation forms, instructions on interviewing, research findings, and reports. A final report, "Problems and Prospects of Small Farmers in Uttar Pradesh in 1969-70," was issued in 1971.
